title: Sustainable side-stream management in Swedish food processing companies using external actors and biogas solutions - Frontiers
summary: The article discusses how food processing companies manage their side-streams to improve sustainability performance by upcycling bio-residuals into high-value products. It highlights the preference for external partners over investing in innovative technology themselves and emphasizes the role of biogas solutions in side-stream management.
green_innovation: TRUE: The article aligns with the definition of green innovation as it focuses on improving sustainability in food processing companies through the management of side-streams and the utilization of biogas solutions.
business_innovation: FALSE: While the article discusses innovations within the food processing industry, the primary focus is on sustainability and waste management rather than traditional business innovations.
green_product: TRUE: The article addresses green products in the context of food processing companies managing side-streams, which involves the development of sustainable practices and the creation of high-value products from bio-residuals.
green_process: TRUE: The article emphasizes green processes by highlighting methods adopted by food processing companies to minimize environmental impacts, reduce waste, and promote sustainability, particularly through the use of biogas solutions in side-stream management.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311119 - Other Animal Food Manufacturing, 562213 - Solid Waste Combustors and Incinerators, 562219 - Other Nonhazardous Waste Treatment and Disposal, 221119 - Other Electric Power Generation
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it focuses on genuine efforts by food processing companies to improve sustainability and manage side-streams in an environmentally responsible manner.

title: Upcycling Initiatives Turn Railway Industry Waste Materials into Creative Products - The Japan News
summary: The article discusses upcycling and recycling initiatives in the railroad industry, transforming discarded items into new products such as slippers, shoehorns, iron kettles, and more, which are attracting new fans and contributing to waste reduction and circular economy efforts.
green_innovation: TRUE. This is green innovation as it involves initiatives in the railroad industry that recycle and upcycle discarded items into new products, contributing to waste reduction and circular economy efforts.
business_innovation: TRUE. This is a business innovation as it involves the creation of new products and processes, such as slippers, shoehorns, and iron kettles, from discarded items in the railroad industry, introducing new goods to the market.
green_product: TRUE. This is a green product as it involves creating environmentally friendly goods like slippers made from recycled seat covers, shoehorns from worn overhead wires, and iron kettles from melted-down steel rails, focusing on reducing waste and promoting sustainability.
green_process: TRUE. This is a green process as it involves methods and techniques in the manufacturing and production of goods in the railroad industry that minimize environmental impacts, promote sustainability, reduce waste, conserve resources, and reuse materials.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 336510 Railroad Rolling Stock Manufacturing, 336390 Other Motor Vehicle Parts Manufacturing, 332999 All Other Miscellaneous Fabricated Metal Product Manufacturing, 339920 Sporting and Athletic Goods Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE. This text does not appear to be an example of greenwashing as it discusses genuine efforts by the railroad industry to create new products through upcycling and recycling initiatives, contributing to waste reduction and sustainability goals.

title: what design can do reveals the 13 winners of the make it circular challenge - Designboom
summary: What Design Can Do announces the winners of the Make it Circular Challenge. Thirteen projects focusing on building a more circular society are chosen to receive awards and development training. Winners include initiatives like 'Guiding the Runoff,' 'Balena,' 'Nivogo,' and 'Alterist Marketplace.' Each project aims to promote sustainability and address environmental challenges.
green_innovation: TRUE: The Make it Circular Challenge by What Design Can Do, in partnership with the IKEA Foundation, identifies and supports innovative projects focused on developing circular economy solutions, which align with environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: TRUE: The Make it Circular Challenge introduces new strategies and projects for building a more circular society, involving innovative approaches to product design, recycling, and sustainable practices, thereby qualifying as business innovation.
green_product: TRUE: Initiatives like 'Balena,' which introduces a new type of bioplastic that is both durable and compostable, and 'Alterist Marketplace,' a platform for upcycled products, align with the definition of green products by significantly reducing environmental impacts throughout their life cycle.
green_process: TRUE: Projects such as 'Guiding the Runoff,' which focuses on adaptive reuse and urban renewal, and 'Resortecs,' developing solutions for textile disassembly and recycling, adhere to green process principles by minimizing environmental impacts, promoting sustainability, and reducing waste.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 541410 - Interior Design Services, 541430 - Graphic Design Services, 611710 - Educational Support Services, 611430 - Professional and Management Development Training
greenwashing: FALSE: The article highlights authentic projects recognized by What Design Can Do, emphasizing their impactful solutions for environmental challenges and promoting sustainability. There is no indication of false or misleading environmental claims, thus not constituting greenwashing.

title: Q&A: Carbonwave expands seaweed emulsifier as demand grows - CosmeticsDesign.com USA
summary: Carbonwave received a $5 million investment to expand production of their seaweed-based cosmetic emulsifier, SeaBalance 2000, which has gained traction. The upcycling of Sargassum seaweed into this product presents a sustainable solution to an environmental issue, with potential for further innovation in the cosmetics industry.
green_innovation: TRUE. This innovation aligns with green principles by upcycling Sargassum into a sustainable cosmetic emulsifier, addressing environmental challenges and promoting sustainability.
business_innovation: TRUE. The introduction of SeaBalance 2000 as a novel cosmetic emulsifier represents a significant improvement in the firm's product offerings, showcasing a new approach to the market.
green_product: TRUE. SeaBalance 2000 qualifies as a green product as it is designed from upcycled Sargassum seaweed, contributing to environmental sustainability goals in its production and usage.
green_process: TRUE. The process of upcycling Sargassum seaweed to create SeaBalance 2000 demonstrates a green process by minimizing environmental impacts and promoting sustainability in cosmetic production.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325620 Toilet Preparation Manufacturing, 324110 Petroleum Refineries, 325411 Medicinal and Botanical Manufacturing, 325411 Pharmaceutical Preparation Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE. The description of SeaBalance 2000 and its development process aligns with genuine environmental considerations, without appearing to mislead about its sustainability impact.

title: Tiger breaks beer-making boundaries to keep up with 'sessionable and accessible' drinking trends - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: Tiger introduced Tiger Soju Infused Lager, inspired by Korean culture and catering to evolving drinking trends in Asia. The product comes in two flavors, with an easy-to-drink profile aimed at a wider consumer base. Tiger engaged South Korean artist G-DRAGON as its global brand ambassador and hosted an event to celebrate the product launch.
